I have it too and instantly turned to Google to help me understand more before meeting with the specialist.  I'll post the website in another comment. It explains how to add proteins with carbs to help break them down.

Very low carb is safe during pregnancy - as long as you are getting plenty of non-starchy vegetables, protein and healthy fats.   Your baby doesn't know whether you eat carbs or not, but what does affect it is high blood sugar.  There is no evidence that eating low carb is dangerous in pregnancy (but there is plenty of evidence that high blood sugar is dangerous to both mother and baby).  So you need to adopt a diet and activity level that will result in controlled blood sugar.If you cannot control your blood sugar with diet / exercise, you need to be given insulin, which will surely be effective when used properly.
